title: Will the UN declare that a famine exists in any part of Yemen in 2021?
preds:
UN to cut food aid to Yemen amid funding shortfall - Al Jazeera English
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/12/22/wfp-forced-to-cut-food-aid-to-yemen-amid-lacking-funds
Wed, 22 Dec 2021 10:13:59 GMT
a63220910974d694c8bf595d6998a54b Saudi-led coalition launches 'large-scale' Yemen operation after deadly strike - FRANCE 24
https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20211225-saudi-led-coalition-launches-large-scale-yemen-operation-after-deadly-strike
Sat, 25 Dec 2021 09:14:15 GMT
094079c2d3b535d9874117b189782a58 I was at: 3%
I am at: <1%
Reasoning: Passage of time. In addition, per a63220910974d694c8bf595d6998a54b, the UN is cutting short its aid relief. Declaring a famine right after that would look fairly bad. Per 094079c2d3b535d9874117b189782a58, the Saudis are launching a new attack, which means that news and international orgs will likely not have enough access to the region to declare a famine in time.

https://apnews.com/article/united-nations-general-assembly-middle-east-united-states-saudi-arabia-united-nations-e9092fbed471e2fe387a395558bdbc28
As is customary, the rich folks are courageously and steadfastly against war and starvation but have momentarily misplaced their checkbooks.   Sooner or later the NGOs will run out of resources.  Stay tuned.

Millions ‘one step away’ from famine in Yemen, UN warns - Al Jazeera English
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/24/millions-one-step-away-from-famine-in-yemen-un-warns
Tue, 24 Aug 2021 08:14:37 GMT “5 million Yemenis one step away from famine” - Tehran Times
https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/464322/5-million-Yemenis-one-step-away-from-famine
Wed, 25 Aug 2021 14:42:27 GMT

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/24/millions-one-step-away-from-famine-in-yemen-un-warns
Rising at least part way from its recent slumber on this issue, the UN has entered the "view with alarm" stage.  I'll probably come up some more as the situation develops, which in this case means deteriorates.

Yemen currency clash deepens crisis in war-torn country - Al Jazeera English
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/22/yemen-currency-clash-deepens-crisis-in-war-torn-country
Sun, 22 Aug 2021 10:36:31 GMT Both the government and the Iran-backed Houthis used the same notes until late 2019 when the rebels banned new banknotes printed in government-run Aden over concerns about inflation. The resulting difference in money supply has since seen the riyal’s value plummet to about 1,000 to the dollar in government areas, while the value in Houthi-controlled zones has held relatively stable at 600. Citizens and businesses in both government and rebel-controlled zones have been left out of pocket by the divergence, but especially those in the former, given rampant inflation there. As the riyal plummeted to new lows in recent weeks in government areas, the central bank there pledged to withdraw the series of banknotes that had accumulated in its territory after the Houthi ban in late 2019. The central bank in Aden was caught out because it had expected the new notes to eventually spread evenly through both zones, but the concentration of supply in the government zone stoked inflation there and spurred the exchange rate divergence. The government this month introduced a stockpile of what it claims were “old bills”, drawing the ire of the rebels who accused it of minting new “counterfeit” money.

With the large amount of aid earmarked for Yemen aid to offset any famine (link), the UN seemly unlikely to announce or declare a famine given that a large amount of aid are flowing into the country without the need for a declaration of famine (the underlying main reason to declare a famine being to galvanize international aid and peacekeeping efforts).  https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/9/us-announces-165-million-humanitarian-aid-to-yemen

US announces $165M in humanitarian aid to Yemen - Al Jazeera English
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/8/9/us-announces-165-million-humanitarian-aid-to-yemen
Mon, 09 Aug 2021 16:46:47 GMT

My rationale is naive again. It is that famines are incredibly rare events, the UN would have to declare it, and there are multiple countries in contention to be the next famine stricken country, which divides the chances among them (though that could also mean that one of them is destined to have the designation and Yemen is contender #1). Probabilistically, however, I don't think so. What backs up my confidence to remain low is the forecast provided by other users that show an improvement over the next few months.

Conflict and Economic Collapse in War-torn Yemen Worsening Hunger Crisis - VOA Asia
https://www.voanews.com/middle-east/conflict-and-economic-collapse-war-torn-yemen-worsening-hunger-crisis
Wed, 28 Jul 2021 16:33:33 GMT Yemen currency devalues to historic lows, exacerbating hunger needs, warns IRC - International Rescue Committee
https://www.rescue.org/press-release/yemen-currency-devalues-historic-lows-exacerbating-hunger-needs-warns-irc
Wed, 21 Jul 2021 08:28:46 GMT Statement by WFP Executive Director on Qatari funding for humanitarian operations in Yemen - Yemen - ReliefWeb
https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/statement-wfp-executive-director-qatari-funding-humanitarian-operations-yemen
Thu, 22 Jul 2021 10:23:23 GMT U.S. envoy back in Gulf to push Yemen truce as battles spread
July 28, 202110:57 AM CEST
https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/us-envoy-back-gulf-push-yemen-truce-battles-spread-2021-07-28/
No priors or domain knowledge.  Averaging the last two forecasts.

The UN has declared famines in 2 counties in the last decade. In South Sudan in 2017, over 32% of the population was in Phase 3 or above, compared to the most recent report of 25% in Yemen. South Sudan had similar issues with conflict, but currently there is also the coronavirus pandemic. Given the infrequency of these conditions being met, I imagine a low base rate, which I am adjusting upward due to the incentive toward action as richer countries start recovering from the coronavirus pandemic.

I think they have had famine for a while, the UN just haven't been able to get the personnel in there to actually record and diagnose it. And I don't see that changing. Apparently Britain is the quill holder in the United Nations, meaning that any UN declaration on this issue has to be initiated by Britain and I think they have become rather hands off on the situation. I am bringing my forecast down rather low to compensate for my higher forecasts earlier
Some people imagine they are evil. Some people don’t have to imagine. Some people imagine they are good, and they are the worst.

Yemen Says Rebel, Government Clashes Kill 111 in 3 Days - Voice of America
https://www.voanews.com/middle-east/yemen-says-rebel-government-clashes-kill-111-3-days
Sun, 27 Jun 2021 08:14:18 GMT
While I'm pretty confident there's a famine happening right now, I believe that the war conditions will prohibit them from actually diagnosing it.

The European Union provides support for WFP's famine relief efforts in Yemen - Yemen - ReliefWeb
https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/european-union-provides-support-wfps-famine-relief-efforts-yemen
Mon, 07 Jun 2021 11:52:15 GMT Yet I still remain low, per https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/

WFP ramps up support to Yemen's famine risk areas - Yemen - ReliefWeb
https://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/wfp-ramps-support-yemens-famine-risk-areas
Mon, 24 May 2021 10:47:03 GMT
No "emergency" or higher designation currently found on linked Yemen "food insecurity phase" maps, This may be temporary: https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen

https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen
2 areas now marked as acute 
https://news.un.org/en/story/2021/03/1086932
Down 1% every 2 weeks. The lean season is now... just need to hold on through June.
Raising probability due to new UN projections
Dropping forecast down a little closer to the 'crowd', for now. https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/food-security-outlook/february-2021

Yet another perspective: 7/30 past years had a famine. Say this year is gonna be 8th. 8/31 years with a famine, or 26%. Multiply .26 by remaining time of year, you get 20. Maybe divide by 4 because Yemen could be any of the four countries on the brink of famine. However, with so much time remaining, let us use 20.

Although the current Suez blockage could delay humanitarian aid and make things worse in the hardest hit area of Hajjah and Amran for a brief period of time, I don't see it hitting famine level and  FEWSNET projects improvement in this region to Crisis phase 3 in the coming months. There was a relaxation in the fuel blockade last week, although this may only be temporary, it is a good sign and even a brief end to the blockage could delay crisis hitting famine levels through 2021.

But let's say 6% is too low. Let's say instead of a 1/17 chance it's doubly more likely, at 1/8. Now it's about 12%. Another set of alternative numbers produces about 10%. Thus I will nestle in-between, at 11%.

Approx 7 years in last 30 years had at least one famine declared. 4 countries are on the brink of famine in 2021. Factor in that Phase 5 is relatively rare. Factor in time passing. Maybe factor in uncertainty of model. I would forecast 1% but I'm gonna stick to 6%.

Based on current and project Integrated Food Security Phase Classifications, the metric for UN's declaration of famine. 45-50% of pop. are rated at 3 or higher (1-5 scale) in current and projected food insecurity assessments. However, bulk of population currently experiencing 2 (Stressed) to 3 (Crisis) phases of food insecurity. 0% are at IPC Phase 5, a famine. Forecast may shift if greater % of pop. start to move toward higher IPC phases. http://www.ipcinfo.org/ipc-country-analysis/details-map/en/c/1152947/?iso3=YEM
Reducing forecast due to US pressure on Saudi Arabia to end conflict. https://www.ft.com/content/e9d17d5d-1f14-4bc9-aa45-1f2dc4fcfa7f
Drop due to ceasefire deal, which may promote more humanitarian aid.
Reducing due to possibility of peace deal. https://www.zerohedge.com/geopolitical/saudi-arabia-floats-peace-deal-end-war-yemen-spark-economic-revival

The following link is comprehensive enough for me to drop back down to baseline. The UN's weekly newsletter does not mention Yemen this week. I only recall it being mentioned once or twice since January? I have also made a fire forecast on this site that is lower than the crowd's, so maybe there is a link. https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen

By end of year at current rate according to the model I linked to, the potential famine situation will only be about 60–80% complete in terms of getting to 20% of the population and in terms of chronological time to get to 20%. If this growth were exponential, it would reach 20% by October ish but 70–80% of the remaining time till 2022 would have already elapsed. And with Campbell's Law / Goodhart's Law, I believe if the numbers approach critical levels, the chances go down because human intervention will increase. Similar to how COVID models can predict catastrophic numbers before humans realize what's going on and try to prove the model wrong.
Given the base rate and the acute situation already facing the country, poor results at fundraising, I am unfortunately more confident than the consensus that there will be a famine declared.

This is a very disturbing map
https://hungermap.wfp.org/?_ga=2.192297770.1452894778.1615971541-3064242.1615971541
The UN has high levels of food hunger reported in Yemen and we have another summer to go through.  Given we are furthest away from a harvest then things are only likely to get worse.  Especially as aid is going to be scares this year 
https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/03/553212-yemen-brink-famine-warns-un-food-relief-agency-chief-appealing-resources-and

Per usual, calling a famine by an international body is low probability.  "Protracted conflict and poor macroeconomic conditions in Yemen continue to disrupt livelihoods, reduce access to income, and drive significantly above-average food prices. Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes are widespread, even in the presence of large-scale humanitarian assistance in many areas, with pockets of Emergency (IPC Phase 4) outcomes likely. In the February to May period, Emergency (IPC Phase 4) outcomes are expected at the governorate level in Hajjah and Amran as the lean season progresses. Although not the most likely scenario, Famine (IPC Phase 5) would be possible if food supply is cut off for a prolonged period of time." https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen

I am more confident than the crowd since the current situation and projection until mid-year* (and looming summer season) have increased my confidence that one will be declared in ANY part of Yemen -- different story if it was for the entire country. My understanding is that 20% of a region has to be in Phase 5 "famine" to be declared a famine, and the UN needs to recognize this finding. Please correct this information if needed. *http://www.ipcinfo.org/ipc-country-analysis/details-map/en/c/1152947/
USAID has just resumed which would lower the odds.

"..Although not the most likely scenario, Famine (IPC Phase 5) would be possible if food supply is cut off for a prolonged period of time." 
Source: https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/key-message-update/january-2021

Major food insecurity will lead to famine yet will it meet the question criteria as far as the time goes.
Phase 3 IPC ==16 districts and a total133 district’s are in a food crisis 
And with the blockade of Yemen the UN will be involved 
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blockade_of_Yemen#:~:text=The%20blockade%20of%20Yemen%20refers%20to%20a%20sea%2C,United%20States%20joined%20the%20blockade%20in%20October%202016.

Yemen is already experiencing a famine by most of the UN's measures. The UN's technical definition of famine (see first source) is "A famine declaration requires evidence of crude death rates higher than two per 10,000 people per day, a global acute malnutrition rate greater than 30 percent, and an extreme lack of food affecting more than 20 percent of the population."  Whether or not the UN will declare if a famine is the main issue at question.  As @erikbays and @SE_Meyer, pointed out, the UN donor conference recently did very poorly. In addition, the situation in Yemen seems to be deteriorating rapidly per the UN IPC estimate from Feb 2021 (see second source). Lastly, UN bureaucrats are already warning that the UN will probably be forced by a lack of aid to declare a famine in Yemen this year. (see third source). High likelihood that famine will be declared in Yemen sometime this year, barring an increase in aid or an end to the war.  1. https://www.thenewhumanitarian.org/analysis/2018/03/05/how-declare-famine-primer-south sudan#:~:text=A%20famine%20declaration%20requires%20evidence,criteria%20to%20project%20a%20famine.
2. http://www.ipcinfo.org/fileadmin/user_upload/ipcinfo/docs/IPC_Yemen_Acute_Malnutrition_2020Jan2021Mar.pdf
3. https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20210302-yemen-step-away-from-devastating-famine-un

The United Nations is projecting that famine will hit Yemen this year. They needed $3.85 billion in aid to prevent famine, and only $1.7 billion was pledged. It's possible that due to the current economic trouble caused by covid the countries involved may not even make good on those pledges. the United States has stated that it would stop its aid for the Saudi Arabia coalition that is attacking civilian targets such as grain silos and water treatment plants and cranes that unload ships at the harbor and cattle, but so far the United States is still assisting Saudi Arabia with intelligence and airplane parts and other assistance.
https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/801280-famine-in-yemen

Recent UN fundraising only raised half of what they said they needed to prevent famine. UK cut its aid by 1/2. Saudi blockade is still in effect. Obviously the articles are written to try to drum up aid, but that doesn't make the reporting inaccurate. All it takes is one province to be given famine status. https://www.newstatesman.com/world/middle-east/2021/03/mass-famine-looms-yemen-and-international-community-standing

The Houthis' rebels most important battle for invasion and control of the Marib governorate could fail, which (alongside the Biden administration's end of a one-sided support for the KSA) increases the likelihood of an end to war and fights.
"A stalemate may be the best-case scenario for now. The IRG can claim to have fought off the Houthis and saved the city, which is as important for the IRG as it is for Yemen as a whole. Marib city is one of the places in Yemen that point toward a viable future. The IRG, local government, and tribal elites have worked together to build and re-build functioning state and local institutions from the ground up."
https://jamestown.org/program/yemens-fate-hinges-on-the-battle-for-marib/

"Disappointing" U.N. pledging conference results on Monday. Maintaining forecast for now. 
https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/launching-donor-conference-amid-fears-famine-yemen-76178739

"Sweden and Switzerland are set to host a donor conference, where countries are to be urged to contribute to funds for poorer nations; United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres is set to appeal for $3.85 billion in relief aid for Yemen."
https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/world-news/yemen-could-be-heading-towards-mass-famine/funding/slideshow/81268727.cms
i thought famine would be the next clarion call of disaster but it looks like real Bird Flu is going to suffice for fear mongers.

The situation is not going to improve until Saudi Arabia lifts their blockades. the biggest reason why a famine might not be declared is because the United Nations can't get access to make an evaluation.
Reducing forecast due to delisting of rebels as a terrorist organisation.
More importantly will NATO support a UN decision secondary to Saudi’s Arabia calling a cease of action.

There have been famines declared in 1984 (Ethiopia), 1991 (Somalia), 1996 (North Korea), 2000 (Ethiopia), 2008 (Sudan) and 2011 (Somalia) and 2017 (South Sudan).
https://news.un.org/en/story/2011/07/382072-un-declares-famine-two-regions-southern-somalia
https://news.un.org/en/story/2017/02/551812-famine-declared-region-south-sudan-un Therefore, the likelihood of a famine being declared in 2021 (4 years since 2017) based on the year gaps between each famine ->
3 = 4 = 5 = 6 = 7 = 8 = 1/6 = 17% is ->
X = 33% = 2/6 = (3 + 4) Yemen one of the four most likely countries currently facing famine ->
http://www.fao.org/news/story/en/item/1325054/icode/ X = 8% = 33% * 1/4 But looking at the severity of the situation there ->
https://fews.net/east-africa I will increase it ->
X = 25%

Decreasing following the Houthis being delisted as a terrorist organization and the US no longer providing arms to Saudi Arabia for the war. Both of these will help humanitarian aid organizations get food to people making a declaration of famine less likely. https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-iran-saudi-arabia-terrorism-yemen-a27a35e70ed6a22ff3dd6b801f7aec2c

I actually think this could reasonably sit at 49% in light of potentially resolving on a technicality, for all intents and purposes, Yemen is already experiencing a famine. The designation has lagged the better half of a year. That said, it appears aid will be administered unhindered going forward and official designation may never come. With two months until the lean season, my thought is that international efforts have time to mobilize. We'll need to review Apr-Jun and then after that a dramatic decline in likelihood. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Famine_in_Yemen_(2016%E2%80%93present)
https://fews.net/east-africa/yemen/food-security-outlook/october-2020
Lowering forecast for now on Houthi terrorist designation reversal by the Biden admin.:  https://www.cnn.com/2021/02/05/politics/us-houthis-terrorist-list/index.html
Reducing forecast following further announcements by Biden regarding  Saudi Arabia. https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/feb/04/us-end-support-saudi-led-operations-yemen-humanitarian-crisis?

I'm reducing my forecast somewhat due to Biden's recent announcement that he is "ending" the US involvement in the war in Yemen. however, they have not yet announced whether they are going to reverse the ruling that the houthis are terrorists. this seems to me a situation where Biden says one thing to the US public and says a different thing to Saudi Arabia. he declares his involvement in the war over to the United states, and then to Saudi Arabia he appeases them by keeping the terrorist designation in place. if they were going to revoke the designation, why haven't they already done so? There is nothing to "review". If the houthi terrorist designation is not reversed within a few weeks I will raise my forecast significantly. If it doesn't happen soon, it's not going to, and if that designation remains in place we will certainly see famine.
Reducing my estimate due to Blinken's review of terrorist designation.

the United Nations states that 50,000 people are already in famine in the country, it's just that no specific region on that map has turned to level 5 yet. I'm reducing my forecast slightly because there is a bill in Congress to remove the terror designation on the houthis and to exit the United States from the Yemen conflict. If that bill were to pass I believe Biden would have a hard time vetoing it and it could effectively eliminate the possibility of famine. I will modify my forecast depending on the outcome of the bill. I know the Biden administration has campaigned that they will reverse course on the US relationship with Saudi Arabia and on the Yemen conflict, but I am very skeptical. That is exactly the kind of thing that a politician would say during a campaign. In practice I think a president like Biden would be very hesitant to upset Saudi Arabia because of their control over the petrodollar. There is good reason why Saudi Arabia was able to play such a major role in 9/11 and commit the alleged murder of Khashoggi and get away with it without repercussion from the United States. Middle East politics is very simple. The United States does whatever Saudi Arabia and Israel want. If the Biden administration was going to reverse the order to declare Houthis as terrorists, why didn't they just do it? Why do they have to do a "review"?
the United Nations states that 50,000 people are already in famine in the country, it's just that no specific region on that map has turned to level 5 yet.

IPC only permits classification of Famine when all regular IPC protocols and special Famine protocols are met. The special protocols are:
1.)  Requirement of reliable evidence on the three outcomes (Food Consumption or Livelihood Change, Global Acute Malnutrition and Crude Death Rate), all of which are either currently or projected to be above Famine Thresholds (>20% of households with extreme food gaps, >30% of children acutely malnourished, and CDR> 2/10,000/day).
2.)  Undergoing a Famine Review Process to validate the classification.
3.)  Development of IPC Famine Alert adhering to pre-determined standards. All to say it is incredibly challenging to declare a famine by meeting all criteria.  COVID will exacerbate the problem but hard to tell if it will push Yemen into "declared" famine territory.  The last two instances of the UN declaring famine was in 2011 and 2017.  This is not intended to show a trend in time but simply the scarcity that it is declared.

Decreasing my forecast slightly because while there is a severe food problem in Yemen, the bar for the UN to declare a famine exists is high. This is a technical process that does not occur frequently and the UN has been criticized in the past for taking so long to declare a famine. Additionally, the Biden administration froze most of the sanctions on the Houthis to allow for humanitarian aid and is currently reviewing the foreign terrorist organization designation. I think this designation will be revoked and humanitarian aid organizations will be able to supply just enough food for the UN to not declare a famine. https://www.cbsnews.com/news/houthis-yemen-joe-biden-us-financial-transactions-humanitarian-aid-terrorist-designation/
https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/22/politics/houthi-designation-review/index.html

"Famine seems to be the hardest word—an outcome no one working to end hunger wants, not least Margot van der Velden, Head of Emergencies at the World Food Programme (WFP).[...]
and it’s why WFP is calling for US$5 billion to set up a rapid-response fund and do its utmost to make sure famine does not happen."
https://www.wfp.org/stories/hunger-hotspots-2021-world-food-programme-united-nations-famine-food-aid
https://www.wfp.org/emergencies/yemen-emergency "New Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis for Yemen indicates that pockets of famine-like conditions (IPC Phase 5) have already returned for the first time in two years, and warns that the number of people experiencing this degree of catastrophic food insecurity could nearly triple from 16,500 currently to 47,000 people between January and June 2021." (as of 03 December 2020)
https://www.wfp.org/news/window-prevent-famine-yemen-narrowing-un-agencies-warn
http://www.ipcinfo.org/fileadmin/user_upload/ipcinfo/docs/IPC_Yemen_Acute_Food_Insecurity_2020Oct2021June_Snapshot.pdf "Earlier this week, U.S. President Joe Biden also issued a temporary pause to arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the UAE as his administration reviewed the exports. The move came as the Biden administration also designated Houthis a terrorist group despite calls against it over its possible humanitarian consequences. "This common vision helps us improve a new dialogue with the U.S. to manage the relationships in the Mediterranean in a more balanced way,” Quartapelle said. The United Nations describes Yemen's war – a conflict seen as a proxy war between Riyadh and Tehran – as the world's largest humanitarian crisis, with 80% of its people in need of aid due to chaos since 2015." https://www.dailysabah.com/world/mid-east/italy-permanently-blocks-arms-sales-to-saudi-arabia-uae-over-yemen The mechanisms of this conflict make it hard to predict. However, the main road to avoiding an even more severe hunger crisis appears to be putting the Iran/KSA proxy war to an end by
/renewed negotiations with Iran on all topics, on different levels (bilateral, multi-lateral, int. organizations) and simultaneously
/disarmament of groups supported by KSA and UAE, and the total stop of weapon sales to any Arab country involved in the conflict. The humanitarian aid, which currently does not reach many people affected by the chaos due to continuously moving and complex battle lines, needs to be more effective by stopping the fights, which should also mitigate the key driver of the continued food insecurity.
One important factor will be the designation of the Houthi rebels as a foreign terrorist organisation by the outgoing Trump administration in mid-January 2021, which could "tip Yemen into a large scale-famine and chill peace efforts.", according to humanitarian aid organizations.
The Biden WH administration recently said it will allow all transactions [of aid and payments] for one month while it reviews the Houthi rebel designation. Meanwhile, "Head of Yemen’s Southern Transitional Council (STC) Aidarus Al Zoubaidi is expected today [30 January 2021] to visit Russia at the start of a tour that will take him to some European countries, according to media reports.
Al Zoubaidi will lead a number of STC officials on the trip that will take several days, Yemeni news portal Adan Al Ghad said.
He is expected to discuss the implementation of a power-sharing pact mediated by Saudi Arabia and signed by the STC and the Yemeni government in 2019.[...]
Last month, a new Yemeni government was formed as part of the Riyadh Agreement, which ended a months-long feud between both Hadi’s authority and the STC to refocus efforts on fighting Al Houthi rebels."
https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/yemen/yemen-stc-head-to-visit-russia-1.1612023077835
http://www.peaceagreements.org/masterdocument/2235
https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20191008-yemen-imminent-agreement-to-hand-over-aden-to-saudi-arabia/ As a short term measure to raise lacking funds for Yemen to remedy the acute threat of famine for 4.9m people, WFP will be forced to cut funds assigned for other locations, WFP Executive Director David Beasley said on 14 January 2021.
"He made an appeal for Gulf states to step up and deliver the funds required to save lives in Yemen.
'If they don’t,' he said, 'we are going to have to take money from the great needs we are facing, whether it’s in the Sahel or Ethiopia or Sudan, South Sudan, DRC [Democratic Republic of Congo] … we are not going to have enough money which means we are going to have famine in many, many other countries. The ripple effect is just beginning from COVID.' " There are currently 50,000 people in Yemen living under famine conditions, but it seems a respective UN declaration is lacking for a region so far.
" 'The world cannot stand by as Yemen slips into famine and millions of vulnerable children and families go hungry,' said UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore. 'The situation is already catastrophic, and without urgent action more children will die. We have prevented famine in Yemen before, and we should be able to prevent it again, with increased support and with unimpeded access to every child and family in need.' "
https://www.wfp.org/news/window-prevent-famine-yemen-narrowing-un-agencies-warn Further reading
https://www.unicef.org/media/91626/file/Yemen%20Humanitarian%20Situation%20Report%201%20-%2030%20Nov%202020.pdf [as of 26 January 2021)
https://www.wfp.org/stories/world-food-programme-warns-worsening-famine-yemen

The ongoing crisis in Yemen is only continuing. As new policies put more pressure on the belligerents, fighting is likely to intensify and exacerbate food insecurity. There are few effective actions currently being taken to avoid this outcome. https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/14/world/middleeast/yemen-famine-houthis.html

The criteria to declare a famine is surprisingly restrictive. One hasn't been declared (that I can see) since 2017 in South Sedan. (https://news.un.org/en/story/2020/11/1077872) Yemen is only one of 8 countries that satisfies the “alarming” criteria (35-49.9), although no official score was provided due to incomplete data available. The website notes that its possible Yemen could fall into the “extremely alarming” category, but that they cannot make the determination officially without the data. (https://www.globalhungerindex.org/ranking.html; https://www.globalhungerindex.org/designations.html) Biden administration has also suspended some sanctions on Yemen which should slow the rate at which the economic situation in Yemen degrades. COVID-19, a main contributing factor, is also being mitigated (gradually, admittedly) by the introduction of vaccines. I don't know how quickly we will be able to distribute these to insecure nations like Yemen, however. https://www.usnews.com/news/politics/articles/2021-01-25/biden-administration-suspends-some-sanctions-on-yemen-rebels

16 districts of Yemen are in Emergency (IPC Phase 4). Phase 5 is famine. 
Different humanitarian agencies and international NGOs have stated that it is increasingly difficult to bring food to the conflict zones and that there are not enough financial resources to attend the populations in need of food (80% of the population subsists through humanitarian assistance).

What is a famine? The UN follows the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) – The IPC lays out 3 things:
1. At least one in five households faces an extreme lack of food, as evidenced by insufficient food consumption (in terms of quantity and/or quality) and by the coping strategies employed by or available to households (e.g. the extent to which assets like livestock or seed may have been sold off)
2. More than 30% of the population is suffering from ‘wasting’ (being below 2 standard deviations below the median weight for a given height in the reference population)
3. Mortality (due to inadequate food consumption): At least two people out of every 10,000 and at least four children under five out of every 10,000 are dying per day. Most up to date WFP emergency dashboard on Yemen: (Yemen population = 29.16m) 16.2m projected food insecure people (IPC 3-5, Jan - Jun 2021)
47,000 projected people under famine (IPC 5 Jan - Jun 2021)
1.7m children under 5 Suffering from Moderate Acute Malnutrition (Nutrition Cluster)
360,000 children under 5 Suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition (Nutrition Cluster) ^https://docs.wfp.org/api/documents/a3c19a4183c44d09b5b9b1cc23621e6b/download/ good data on the history of famine: https://ourworldindata.org/famines#famines-by-world-region-since-1860  Current conditions in Yemen: New Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) analysis for Yemen indicates that pockets of famine-like conditions (IPC Phase 5) have already returned for the first time in two years, and warns that the number of people experiencing this degree of catastrophic food insecurity could nearly triple from 16,500 currently to 47,000 people between January and June 2021. 
https://www.unicef.org/press-releases/window-prevent-famine-yemen-narrowing-un-agencies-warn At least one in five households now faces an extreme lack of food, more than 30 percent of the population is suffering from acute malnutrition, and at least two people out of every 10,000 are dying each day.
https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2017/02/23/516642447/who-declares-a-famine-and-what-does-that-actually-mean The numbers going hungry are expected to worsen in the coming six months. If these projections prove true, 2021 may bring the worst famine the world has seen in decades.

Yemen has had an on-going famine since 2016. The UN declared that the possibility of famine existed in Yemen in October 2018. The stalling of peace efforts between the different parties in the Yemeni civil war and the scaling back of famine relief efforts by the UN due to a lack of funding and the COVID-19 pandemic together mean that the situation in Yemen is unlikely to improve and will most likely get worse. High propensity for a famine to exist and the lack of UN funding increases the likelihood that the UN will use a famine declaration as a rallying cry to galvanize support for relief efforts.

The report says "the caseload in Catastrophe (IPC Phase 5) is mainly found in [the governorates of] Al Jawf, Hajjah and Amra", and that these people who are in Catastrophe are found in the districts of Kharab Al Marashi, Rajuzah, As Sawd, As Sudah, and Qarah. For these five districts the projected changes from Oct-Dec 2020 to Jan-Jun 2021 for people in Catastrophe are:
Kharab Al Marashi  4,500 -> 4,500 out of 87,948
Rajuzah  5,500 -> 11,000 out of 107,671 
As Sawd 1,500 -> 1,500 out of  33,017 
As Sudah  2,000 -> 2,000 out of  42,136 
Qarah 3,000 ->  5,500 out of 55,741 Six new districts within Al Jawf, Hajjah and Amra are projected to have people in Catastrophe in Jan-Jun 2021. These are:
Bart Al Anan 4,000 out of  77,373 
Harf Sufyan  3,000 out of  56,573 
Al Qaflah  2,500 out of  49,655 
Al Ashah  3,000 out of  56,222 
Al Maghrabah  5,000 out of  95,524 
Washhah 5,000 out of  97,948  It seems that if at least 20% of people in a particular area are in Catastrophe, then a famine is declared.

From what I can gather, according to the  Integrated Food Security Phase Classification, developed by the UN: a famine requires:  "At least 20 percent of households face a complete lack of food and/or other basic needs and starvation, death, and destitution are evident; and acute malnutrition prevalence exceeds 30%; and mortality rates exceed 2/10000/day". This level of humanitarian crisis corresponds to IPC phase 5. Recent reports (https://www.unicef.org/press-releases/window-prevent-famine-yemen-narrowing-un-agencies-warn) indicate that the number of people in phase 4 is likely to increase from 3.6 million to 5 million. Even this number of people - note, at phase 4, not the prerequisite phase 5 - the one in five households-number would not have been reached even here, as there are approx 30 million people in Yemen (assuming people to population is a valid proxy for households). The same report suggests that the people currently in phase 5 are set to reach 47,000 by June 2021. Again, not near the 6 million that is required for phase 5. At the same time, half of the population is at/will be at IPC3. As such, it seems that things will have to accelerate quite a bit for IPC5 and Famine categorization to be reached.  I rank it as possible, but not likely.
Famine it Yemen has been ongoing for years now. I think the UN will see more U.S. international involvement, and could look to the U.S. as a supporter of a declared famine in order to gain support.
